panels.description:
This shows the maximum Kafka consumer lag across all instantiated sources. See the other Kafka Consumer Lag panel for per-source details.

For example, if there are 1,000 messages in kafka and materialized has processed 750, this value will be 250.

This is limited by the (low) frequency at which we request metadata from kafka -- it is common for all values to be zero, and there is only a problem if the number is not decreasing.
panels.title: Kafka Consumer Lag

panels.description:
This shows the CPU utilization as proportion of CPUs used. A value of `1.0` means that materialized is using the equivalent of 100% of 1 CPU.

See the CPU/Memory row below for more details.
panels.title: CPU Utilization

panels.description:
Total number of sql data queries being executed per second.

See the client queries row for a detailed breakdown.
panels.title: SQL Queries/second

panels.description:
This encapsulates every kind of query error that materialize returns. 

It includes errors caused by invalid SQL queries, as well as internal materialized errors. All query errors are reported to the materialized log file.
panels.title: SQL Query Error Rate

panels.description:
Alerts configured in the Alerts row.

Note that you will probably want to edit the alerts to match your deployment.
panels.title: Status

panels.description: How many messages per second materialized is currently ingesting
panels.title: Kafka Message Ingest Rate

panels.description: See the CPU/Memory row below for more details.
panels.title: Memory use

panels.description: Median query latency, see SQL Query Timing row for a detailed breakdown.
panels.title: Query Latency

panels.content:
Timely Workers: $timely_workers
Built At: $built_at
Build Version: $build_version
Build sha: $build_sha
panels.title: Materialize Build Info

panels.description:
This shows the distribution of query latencies over time. Brighter colors mean more queries fell into that latency bucket.

This panel complements the histogram quantiles panel by showing the distribution of latencies at any given time in the past.
panels.title: Latency Evolving Histogram ($command)

panels.description:
This shows what percent of queries finished in what amount of time.

The value in parentheses ($command) reflects the postgres commands that are being displayed, "Execute + Query" catches all commands that result in data being returned to SQL clients, other commands drive postgres connection to prepare for data or close connections.
panels.title: Query Latency Quantiles ($command)

panels.description:
This shows the number of messages that materialize knows it is behind an kafka source.

For example, if there are 1,000 messages in kafka and materialized has processed 750, this value will be 250.

This is limited by the (low) frequency at which we request metadata from kafka -- it is common for all values to be zero, and there is only a problem if the number is not decreasing.
panels.title: Kafka Consumer Lag

panels.description:
Unlike the Messages Ingested by Format, this shows the number of messages materialized has ingested per topic.

Currently only shows Kafka
panels.title: Kafka Message Ingest Rate

panels.description: For Materialize instances that have multiple different categories of source (json, avro, etc) this shows the total rate of message ingestion.
panels.title: Messages Ingested by Message Format

panels.description: This is only reported for Kinesis sources at the moment.
panels.title: Time behind external source

panels.description: The number of messages we've written through a Kafka Sink.
panels.title: Kafka Messages Written

panels.description: The number of errors we've received when writing messages to Kafka
panels.title: Kafka Message Write Errors

panels.description:
See also the CPU row in the [node-state dashboard](/d/node-state?var-job=load_test). 

You will need to filter to the current instance: $instances
panels.title: materialized: CPU usage

panels.description:
Per-thread-name CPU usage, multiple trheads (e.g. in a pool) often share the same name. 

See the thread-name-count panel for how many threads exist with a given name.
panels.title: materialized: per-thread-name CPU usage

panels.description:
See also the Memory/Meminfo row in the [node-state dashboard](/d/node-state?var-job=load_test). 

You will need to filter to the current instance: $instances
panels.title: materialized: memory

panels.description:
How many threads exist with a given name in materialized.

Helps think about per-thread CPU usage, in case it's over 100%
panels.title: materialized: thread-name counts

alert.message: No instances of Materialize are running
alert.name: Materialized Instances Up

alert.message: The Commands or Peek queues have been growing continuously for 5 minutes.
alert.name: Worker Queue Growth

panels.description: Shows how the worker queues are behaving. In general they should be stable, if they are growing continuously that means materialized is not keeping up.
panels.title: Worker Queue Growth

panels.description: A worker is the underlying thread of computation in materialized. In general materialized should send similar amounts of work to each worker, and therefore the commands processed per worker should be similar.
panels.title: Worker commands processing rate

panels.description:
A worker is the underlying thread of computation in materialized. In general materialized should send similar amounts of work to each worker, and the queue depths should be similar to each other.

If a queue is growing without bound, or queues are very unbalanced, that could signify a problem.
panels.title: Worker queue sizes

panels.description: Proportion of time spent in maintenance, per arrangement,  for the top 50 arrangements.
panels.title: Time spent in maintenance

panels.description:
This shows the top 10 dataflow operators that are introducing lag into the system.

An operator can introduce lag either because its source is running behind, or because it is doing lots of work.
panels.title: Frontier lags

panels.description: The raw kafka offset as seen at ingest time by materialized.
panels.title: Kafka Offsets Received

panels.description:
A batch is a slab of memory, arrangements with a large number of batches have allocated a large number of records, which should be represented in the Arrangement Records panel.

This shows the top 10 arrangements by number of batches, and should be similar to the Arrangement Records panel.
panels.title: Arrangement Batches

panels.description:
This is expected to be primarily at zero, with very brief spikes.

If any time series is above zero for multiple points that suggests that we are stuck.
panels.title: Number of arrangements in mainenance

panels.description: The difference between the most-consumed and least-consumed kafka partition, in terms of when we last released messages into the dataflow layer.

targets.expr: max by (topic, source_id) (mz_kafka_partition_closed_ts{instance=~"$instance"}) - min by (topic, source_id) (mz_kafka_partition_closed_ts{instance=~"$instance"})
max by (topic, source_id) (mz_partition_closed_ts{instance=~"$instance"}) - min by (topic, source_id) (mz_partition_closed_ts{instance=~"$instance"})

panels.title: Kafka Partition Imbalance Amount

panels.description:
The total number of times that a source has been scheduled, and the rate at which they're scheduled.

In a well-behaved system, sources should be activated approximately in proportion to how much data they have to read. If sources are being scheduled at significantly different proportions it could mean that the more-scheduled sources are having a hard time keeping up.
panels.title: Source Scheduled Count

panels.description:
This is a measure of when we last stated that ingested data was valid for computation. Another way of thinking about this is how many seconds of data do we ingest per second of real time. In a steady state this should be approximately 1s/s.

All sources that have a rate of 0 are *stalled* and are either not ingesting new data or have no new data to ingest.

Internally, this is the capability, and the underlying measure is what capability we have released.
panels.title: Capability Closing Rate

panels.description:
An arrangement is where materialize stores state, records are equivalent to rows in a database or messages in a stream.

This shows the top 10 arrangements by number of records, and should be similar to the Arrangement Batches panel.
panels.title: Arrangement Records

panels.description: A record is equivalent to a row in a traditional database
panels.title: Record increase/second

panels.description: A record is equivalent to a row in a traditional database
panels.title: Total Number of Records
